content:
The festival On April 6th, 2025, many are celebrating a significant and joyous Hindu festival: Ramanavami. This auspicious occasion marks the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh avatar of Lord Vishnu and a revered figure embodying righteousness, courage, and virtue.
Ramanavami falls on the ninth day of the Chaitra month in the Hindu lunar calendar, during the Shukla Paksha (waxing phase of the moon). It is a time for devotees to reflect on the life and teachings of Lord Rama, whose epic tale, the Ramayana, continues to inspire millions with its profound lessons on dharma (righteous conduct), family values, and the triumph of good over evil.
The Significance of Lord Rama Lord Rama is revered as “Maryada Purushottam,” the ideal man. His life exemplifies the highest standards of moral and ethical conduct. He is admired for his unwavering adherence to dharma, his compassion, his courage in the face of adversity, his devotion to his family, and his just rule as a king.
The teachings derived from the Ramayana continue to hold relevance in today’s world. They emphasize the importance of truth, righteousness, loyalty, and the power of good to overcome evil. Ramanavami serves as a reminder of these timeless values and encourages devotees to imbibe them in their own lives.
Food Many make panaka, I made it with muskmelon by making jaggery water with caradamom seeds and adding grinded muskmelon with lemon.
As we observe Ramanavami today, let us reflect on the noble ideals that Lord Rama embodied and strive to incorporate them into our lives. May this festival bring peace, prosperity, and righteousness to all. Jai Shri Ram!
summary:
The festival

On April 6th, 2025, many are celebrating a significant and joyous Hindu festival: Ramanavami. This auspicious occasion marks the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh avatar of Lord Vishnu and a revered figure embodying righteousness, courage, and virtue.

Ramanavami falls on the ninth day of the Chaitra month in the Hindu lunar calendar, during the Shukla Paksha (waxing phase of the moon). It is a time for devotees to reflect on the life and teachings of Lord Rama, whose epic tale, the Ramayana, continues to inspire millions with its profound lessons on dharma (righteous conduct), family values, and the triumph of good over evil.
title: Ramanavami

content:
My First Adventure with Horse Riding Stepping into the world of horseback riding can feel intimidating, especially if your experience with horses extends no further than petting one at a county fair. That’s exactly where I found myself last weekend when I decided to take the plunge with Equine Escapes, a family owned horse ranch nestled in the WA.
Kelly, the owner arrived at the meetup point and I was blown away by the carriage - it was a huge one with 6 horses. We also saw lots of other riders with their horses. It was a sunny day so everyone wanted to enjoy it seems!
Meeting the Herd The six horses that would guide our journey through the wilderness each possessed distinct personalities that quickly became apparent:
Dakota, the undisputed alpha male of the herd, carried himself with quiet confidence and stoic dignity. Diego radiated excitement, his curious eyes constantly scanning the surroundings, seemingly thrilled about the adventure ahead. Jack, my eventual companion, was an Arabian male with a gentle temperament and an insatiable appetite for any patch of grass within reach. Teddy, a gigantic Belgian horse, commanded attention with his majestic presence and powerful frame. Trinity, aptly named “the princess,” carried herself with elegance as the second-in-command of this equine community. Tinker, a sweet-natured female, moved with a mellow grace that instantly put newcomers at ease. It took about 40 minutes to stretch out the horses and get them into the bridle and saddle a few of them up.
I was paired with Jack, positioned third in our single-file formation behind Diego and Dakota. My initial challenge became immediately apparent—Jack’s irresistible urge to sample every patch of grass along the trail required gentle but firm guidance. Through this unexpected test, I gradually mastered what I came to think of as the “gentle approach to discipline,” learning to communicate with my four-legged partner through subtle cues.
To my surprise, the ride proved remarkably comfortable. Despite warnings about soreness that typically plagues first-time riders, my improving posture seemed to align naturally with Jack’s trotting rhythm along the trail.
Our path wound through a lush forest tapestry—dense trees, vibrant undergrowth, and occasional steep inclines that showcased the horses’ sure-footedness. Midway through our journey, we paused for photographs, capturing moments that would later translate the majesty of both the wilderness and our equine companions.
Horse communication 101 The journey also offered an unexpected education in equine communication. The occasional loud flatulence and rhythmic breathing were, as I learned, the horses’ way of signaling their well-being to the rest of the herd. Our guide explained that continuous huffing would indicate distress—a vital piece of knowledge for any aspiring rider.
Perhaps most fascinating was discovering how responsive these intelligent animals were to human positioning. A gentle squeeze of the calf against their sides, accompanied by a soft verbal cue, would set them in motion—a dance of mutual understanding between species.
The hour-long adventure passed with surprising swiftness, leaving me with muscles that recognized their new experience but also with a profound appreciation for these magnificent animals and the wilderness we had traversed together.
summary:
My First Adventure with Horse Riding

Stepping into the world of horseback riding can feel intimidating, especially if your experience with horses extends no further than petting one at a county fair. That’s exactly where I found myself last weekend when I decided to take the plunge with Equine Escapes, a family owned horse ranch nestled in the WA.

Kelly, the owner arrived at the meetup point and I was blown away by the carriage - it was a huge one with 6 horses. We also saw lots of other riders with their horses. It was a sunny day so everyone wanted to enjoy it seems!
title: Horse Trail Ride!

content:
Ollama: Run AI Models Locally with Ease
Artificial intelligence is transforming industries, but running AI models efficiently remains a challenge, especially when cloud-based solutions come with privacy concerns and costs. Ollama is a game-changing tool that allows users to run AI models locally on their machines, offering enhanced privacy, control, and performance.
What is Ollama? Ollama is an open-source framework designed to make running large language models (LLMs) and AI-powered applications on personal hardware easy and efficient. It eliminates the need for constant internet access and expensive cloud infrastructure by enabling local model execution. Whether you are a developer, researcher, or hobbyist, Ollama provides a powerful way to experiment with AI without external dependencies.
Key Features of Ollama Local AI Execution – Run AI models directly on your machine, ensuring privacy and reducing latency. Optimized for Performance – Uses efficient model quantization and hardware acceleration for smooth performance even on consumer-grade hardware. Supports Various Models – Compatible with models like LLaMA, CodeLlama, and other open-source AI models. Flexible and Developer-Friendly – Provides APIs and CLI tools for seamless integration into applications. No Cloud Dependency – Eliminates reliance on third-party servers, reducing operational costs. Why Use Ollama? Privacy & Security: Since models run locally, sensitive data remains on your device. Cost-Effective: Avoid high costs associated with cloud AI services. Offline Functionality: Continue working even without an internet connection. Customization: Fine-tune models to fit specific needs without restrictions from external providers. Getting Started with Ollama To install Ollama, simply download it from the official GitHub repository or website. Once installed, you can load and run models using a few simple commands.
Ollama is revolutionizing the way AI is deployed and used, making it accessible to everyone. Whether you’re a developer working on AI-powered applications or an enthusiast exploring machine learning, Ollama provides the flexibility and power needed to bring AI closer to home.
summary:
Ollama: Run AI Models Locally with Ease

Artificial intelligence is transforming industries, but running AI models efficiently remains a challenge, especially when cloud-based solutions come with privacy concerns and costs. Ollama is a game-changing tool that allows users to run AI models locally on their machines, offering enhanced privacy, control, and performance.

What is Ollama?

Ollama is an open-source framework designed to make running large language models (LLMs) and AI-powered applications on personal hardware easy and efficient. It eliminates the need for constant internet access and expensive cloud infrastructure by enabling local model execution. Whether you are a developer, researcher, or hobbyist, Ollama provides a powerful way to experiment with AI without external dependencies.
title: Ollama

content:
Holi, the festival of colors, is one of the most vibrant and joyous festivals in India, celebrated to mark the arrival of spring and the triumph of good over evil.
This is festival has roots from the Hiranya Kashyapu legend. King Hiranyakashipu, a demon king, was granted a boon that made him nearly invincible and wanted everyone to worship him. His son Prahlad was a devotee of Lord Vishnu which angered him to no end. Enraged, the king plotted to kill Prahlad and sought the help of his sister Holika, who had a magical cloak that made her immune to fire. Holika tricked Prahlad into sitting on a pyre with her, but by divine intervention, the cloak flew off her and covered Prahlad instead. Holika burned to ashes, while Prahlad was saved. This event symbolizes the victory of righteousness (dharma) over evil, and the eve of Holi is marked by Holika Dahan (a bonfire) to commemorate this.
“Bura na mano, Holi hai!” - a popular saying as people smear colors over their friends and family! The Bellevue event was held at Crossroads park and had quite a turnout despite the cloudy cold weather. There was a DJ playing popular songs. Everyone were dancing and it was a happy colorful vibe!
The throwing of colored powder symbolizes unity and the shedding of inhibitions, creating a mesmerizing spectacle of hues. Lots of kids running around and trying to out color their peers haha! We had fun throwing different shades of gulal and dancing our hearts out.
summary:
Holi, the festival of colors, is one of the most vibrant and joyous festivals in India, celebrated to mark the arrival of spring and the triumph of good over evil.

This is festival has roots from the Hiranya Kashyapu legend. King Hiranyakashipu, a demon king, was granted a boon that made him nearly invincible and wanted everyone to worship him. His son Prahlad was a devotee of Lord Vishnu which angered him to no end. Enraged, the king plotted to kill Prahlad and sought the help of his sister Holika, who had a magical cloak that made her immune to fire. Holika tricked Prahlad into sitting on a pyre with her, but by divine intervention, the cloak flew off her and covered Prahlad instead. Holika burned to ashes, while Prahlad was saved. This event symbolizes the victory of righteousness (dharma) over evil, and the eve of Holi is marked by Holika Dahan (a bonfire) to commemorate this.
title: Holi_2025

content:
Introduction to React: Understanding How It Works and Renders What is React? React is a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications where UI updates dynamically without requiring full-page reloads. Developed and maintained by Meta (formerly Facebook), React has become one of the most widely used front-end frameworks due to its declarative and component-based nature.
In this blog post, we’ll dive into how React works, how it renders UI updates efficiently, and what makes it such a powerful tool for modern web development.
Why Use React? Before diving into how React works, let’s look at some reasons why developers prefer it:
Component-Based Architecture: React applications are built using reusable components, making the code modular and maintainable. Virtual DOM for Efficient Rendering: React updates only the necessary parts of the UI instead of re-rendering the entire page. Unidirectional Data Flow: React enforces a one-way data flow, making it easier to manage application state. Rich Ecosystem and Community Support: React has extensive third-party libraries, tools, and a large community to help developers. Cross-Platform Development: React Native allows developers to build mobile applications using React. Now, let’s explore how React works under the hood.
How React Works Components and JSX At its core, React is all about components. A React application is composed of multiple components that represent different parts of the UI. Components can be either functional (simpler and based on functions) or class-based (stateful and based on ES6 classes). However, with the introduction of hooks, functional components have become more prevalent.
React uses JSX (JavaScript XML), a syntax extension that allows developers to write HTML-like code within JavaScript:
function Welcome(props) { return <h1>Hello, {props.name}!</h1>; } This JSX gets compiled into regular JavaScript using Babel before being rendered to the browser.
Virtual DOM and Reconciliation React uses a Virtual DOM (VDOM) to optimize UI updates. The Virtual DOM is a lightweight representation of the actual DOM, allowing React to make efficient updates without modifying the real DOM directly.
Here’s how React updates the UI efficiently:
When a component’s state or props change, React creates a new Virtual DOM tree. It then compares the new Virtual DOM with the previous one using a diffing algorithm. React determines the minimal set of changes required and updates only those parts of the real DOM (a process called reconciliation). This approach significantly improves performance because modifying the real DOM is slow, whereas updating the Virtual DOM is much faster.
React Rendering Lifecycle React follows a lifecycle for rendering components. Understanding this lifecycle is crucial for managing state updates effectively.
Mounting (Initial Rendering) When a component is first rendered, React performs the following steps:
Calls the constructor (for class components) to initialize state. Calls render() to generate the Virtual DOM. Updates the real DOM and invokes lifecycle methods like componentDidMount() (for class components) or useEffect(() => {...}, []) (for functional components). Updating (Re-rendering) When a component’s state or props change, React performs an update cycle:
React detects the change and re-renders the Virtual DOM. It compares the new Virtual DOM with the previous one. It updates only the changed parts of the real DOM efficiently. Lifecycle methods like componentDidUpdate() or useEffect() (with dependencies) run after updates. Unmounting (Cleanup) When a component is removed from the DOM, React cleans up any lingering effects using componentWillUnmount() (for class components) or useEffect(() => {...}, []) return function (for functional components).
React State and Props State and props are crucial concepts in React:
State: A component’s internal data that can change over time (e.g., user input, API responses). Props: Read-only data passed from a parent component to a child component. Example of using state:
import React, { useState } from 'react'; function Counter() { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); return ( <div> <p>Count: {count}</p> <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Increment</button> </div> ); } Here, useState(0) initializes the count state, and setCount updates it.
React Hooks Hooks allow functional components to use state and lifecycle features previously available only in class components. Some important hooks include:
useState(): Manages component state. useEffect(): Handles side effects like API calls. useContext(): Accesses global state without prop drilling. useRef(): References DOM elements or persists values across renders. Example of useEffect() for fetching data:
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; function DataFetcher() { const [data, setData] = useState(null); useEffect(() => { fetch('https://api.example.com/data') .then(response => response.json()) .then(data => setData(data)); }, []); return <div>{data ? JSON.stringify(data) : 'Loading...'}</div>; } Handling Events in React React events work similarly to native DOM events but use camelCase (e.g., onClick instead of onclick). Event handlers are passed as functions.
Example:
function Button() { const handleClick = () => { alert('Button clicked!'); }; return <button onClick={handleClick}>Click Me</button>; } Conditional Rendering React allows rendering components conditionally using JavaScript expressions:
function Greeting({ isLoggedIn }) { return isLoggedIn ? <h1>Welcome back!</h1> : <h1>Please log in.</h1>; } Lists and Keys When rendering lists, React requires a unique key prop to optimize updates.
function List() { const items = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry']; return ( <ul> {items.map((item, index) => ( <li key={index}>{item}</li> ))} </ul> ); } Conclusion React’s efficiency comes from its Virtual DOM, reconciliation process, and component-based structure. Understanding how React renders UI updates helps developers write better, more optimized applications.
If you’re new to React, start with small projects and experiment with state, props, and hooks. With practice, you’ll quickly grasp the power of React and be able to build dynamic, scalable applications.
summary:
Introduction to React: Understanding How It Works and Renders

What is React?

React is a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications where UI updates dynamically without requiring full-page reloads. Developed and maintained by Meta (formerly Facebook), React has become one of the most widely used front-end frameworks due to its declarative and component-based nature.

In this blog post, we’ll dive into how React works, how it renders UI updates efficiently, and what makes it such a powerful tool for modern web development.
title: Intro to React

content:
Wilburton Park Trail Friends and I set off to an afternoon outing because Spring is finally here in Washington! It’s beautifully sunny.
The trail itself seemed pretty isolated although there was a school and field for kids around but it might have just been due to lots of trees around. After 0.2miles we entered the gardens which had just begun to blossom and it was really enjoyable. Many flowers were emitting pleasant aromas!
We wandered around until we finally landed at the visitor center - guess we went in the more backward route haha. Got to see the Japanese themed garden (the pond was mostly dry ironically), talked about Buddhism and origins of Buddha as we wandered about. Next stop was the perennials and the yao garden which had year round green plants such as conifers and daffodils and other plants. Spotted hummingbirds and woodpeckers and a variant of sparrow called Spotted Towhee near the bushes - tried to take a video but our iphones were not equipped for it unfortunately.
The visitor center had lots of flower themed earrings, books on gardening and birds, lots of butterfly themed hairclips and other cute items and with humungous will power, we managed not to give in to the temptations! We saw some sculptures and lots of walking paths and history of the place. It was a cow shed previously (1936 with first human settlement and later converted to a public garden). With 53 acres it contained a lot of wildlife and beauty. And, the red cedar trees could live upto 1000 years! 10 times the lifespan of a human. Plants are amazing. There was also the Gunnera tinctoria which had spiky shaped leaves. The tall oregon grape plant is home to lot of birds with its delicious fruits and yellow flowers.
There was a suspension bridge as well - that many kids and adults alike were delighted by! Got to bounce around and feel like we were on an adventure as we saw the creek below with shallow water. After an hour and a half, we headed back, went on a different trail and had to do a loopback to finally get back to our car. Overall, a pretty enjoyable day! Felt like we acquired relaxed energy and got rid of the afternoon sluggish tendancies with this outing.
Photos Lightning shaped tree spotted by Anurag - we were really surprised by its shape Beautiful aromatic flowers Me with another gigantic tree The park
summary:
Wilburton Park Trail

Friends and I set off to an afternoon outing because Spring is finally here in Washington! It’s beautifully sunny.

The trail itself seemed pretty isolated although there was a school and field for kids around but it might have just been due to lots of trees around. After 0.2miles we entered the gardens which had just begun to blossom and it was really enjoyable. Many flowers were emitting pleasant aromas!
title: Bellevue botanical garden

content:
This Valentine’s day, I want to talk about my city - Bellevue!
Nestled in the heart of the Pacific Northwest, Bellevue, Washington, is a city that perfectly blends urban sophistication with natural beauty. Located just across Lake Washington from Seattle, Bellevue has rapidly grown into a thriving hub for technology, business, and outdoor enthusiasts.
Downtown Bellevue is amazing especially during the nights. Lots of happening places and just beautiful lighting with shopping. Crossroads for all things Asian and Indian. I went to Rasoi and Dosa House for Indian cuisines and both were good for North Indian and South Indian focused food respectively. There are a lot of parks around and the public transport is good enough to get by to most places.
One of the most stunning aspects of Bellevue’s landscape is the breathtaking mountain views visible from downtown. On clear days, I can see:
The Cascade Mountains – Stretching across Washington, the Cascades provide a stunning backdrop, especially when the peaks are covered in snow.
Mount Rainier – Towering at 14,411 feet, this iconic stratovolcano is one of the most majestic sights from Bellevue, dominating the southern skyline.
The Olympic Mountains – To the west, across Puget Sound, the Olympic Mountains add to Bellevue’s picturesque views, creating stunning sunset silhouettes.
I also visited Everett which is north of Bellevue. It’s a quiet residential area and mostly a suburb with lot of Boeing employees as its residents. It has its own rustic charm!
Snoqualmie – Nestled in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains, Snoqualmie is best known for Snoqualmie Falls, a breathtaking 268-foot waterfall that attracts visitors year-round. The town also offers outdoor activities such as hiking, fishing, and skiing at Snoqualmie Pass, making it a perfect getaway for nature lovers.
Redmond – Known as the “Bicycle Capital of the Northwest” and home to Microsoft’s headquarters, Redmond is a thriving tech hub with a strong cycling culture, beautiful parks, and a charming downtown. The city is also famous for lot of Indian restaurants and Costco :P
Next on my list to explore is Bridle trails once the weather gets better and the National Parks in and around here!
summary:
This Valentine’s day, I want to talk about my city - Bellevue!

Nestled in the heart of the Pacific Northwest, Bellevue, Washington, is a city that perfectly blends urban sophistication with natural beauty. Located just across Lake Washington from Seattle, Bellevue has rapidly grown into a thriving hub for technology, business, and outdoor enthusiasts.

Downtown Bellevue is amazing especially during the nights. Lots of happening places and just beautiful lighting with shopping. Crossroads for all things Asian and Indian. I went to Rasoi and Dosa House for Indian cuisines and both were good for North Indian and South Indian focused food respectively. There are a lot of parks around and the public transport is good enough to get by to most places.
title: Bellevue

summary:
Ingredients

Sauce:

1 tbsp Soy Sauce
2 tbsp Sugar
3 tbsp Gochujang
1 tsp Garlic (diced)
1 tbsp red chilli flakes or “Gochugaru”

Stock:

Anchovy broth (optional)
3 cups Water
Enoki mushrooms
Green onion
Cabbage
500g Rice Cakes
Eggs
Ramen noodles

Recipe

  1. Mix the sauce together
  2. Bring water to boil
  3. Add anchovy and simmer
  4. Mix in the sauces
  5. Throw in the veggies and rice cakes and stir till sauce thickens
  6. Add the boiled eggs and ramen
  7. Wait for a few mins till the ramen is cooked and then serve!!
  8. Optional - sprinkle seasame seeds on top!
title: Rabokki (tteokbokki + ramen)

content:
Day 1: Flight to SF Got the window seat Amazing view of the mountains! Went to the hotel, refreshed & headed out Walked around, lot of weed smell, lots of walkers! Went to Salesforce Park - amazing view and plants Went to Pier 39 Sealions, sunset, Bueno Vista cafe with Irish coffee, Lombard street in the dark, Chinese Sizzling Pot King for dinner and back to hotel & sleep! Tv was atrocious at the hotel but the view was amazing
Day 2 Onboarding! Went to chinatown in the evening but everything was mostly closed Got to see the fortune cookie place, had pineapple bun, went to Stella’s pasteries - awesome biscuits & treats, went to Golden Boy Pizza for a slice - so good! Got on the wrong direction bus hahaha, exchanged later on, went to hotel, got indian food & boba tea and slept!
Day 3 Checkout & early morning onboarding 61st floor views were so good! Boarded the expensive bus to Palace Museum and went to the beach to view the Golden Gate Bridge Got the Waymo to hotel, dropped my phone while getting down, raised the complaint, left to San Jose in Bart Met friends, planned a trip! Knocked out with indian dinner
Day 4 Pinnacle National Park - amazing park for beginner hikes! Easy hike with nice view & a cave route which was so cool to climb through. Good descent path and spotted a blue bird, some deer. Missed the concord eagles but apparently common there. Came back and collected my phone.
Day 5 Wrapped up, goodbyes! Flight back to Seatac, saw Alien Romulus Developed a headache, so slept off for rest of day.
All in all, Bay Area is soooo cool!! <3
summary:
Day 1:

Flight to SF Got the window seat Amazing view of the mountains! Went to the hotel, refreshed & headed out Walked around, lot of weed smell, lots of walkers! Went to Salesforce Park - amazing view and plants Went to Pier 39 Sealions, sunset, Bueno Vista cafe with Irish coffee, Lombard street in the dark, Chinese Sizzling Pot King for dinner and back to hotel & sleep! Tv was atrocious at the hotel but the view was amazing
title: Sfo trip

content: Adventure with cleaning blender I was trying to clean my vavsea blender and removed the o ring seal from the blender lid. Then spent a long time trying to figure out how to put it back cuz it was not too expandable and not much space! After wracking our brains (me and a friend), my friend figured out that we could remove the top part of the blender lid from the bottom covering!! Hallelujah! After this it was a piece of cake to put the seal back on and twist it into the lid. Its super funny looking back cuz being an engineer means you’re supposed to figure these things out quicker!
summary:
Adventure with cleaning blender

I was trying to clean my vavsea blender and removed the o ring seal from the blender lid. Then spent a long time trying to figure out how to put it back cuz it was not too expandable and not much space! After wracking our brains (me and a friend), my friend figured out that we could remove the top part of the blender lid from the bottom covering!! Hallelujah! After this it was a piece of cake to put the seal back on and twist it into the lid. Its super funny looking back cuz being an engineer means you’re supposed to figure these things out quicker!
title: Fun_discovery

content:
Reference: https://youtube.com/shorts/fzlokaeYOl8?si=yPBfJaqcNrlCywG2
https://youtu.be/SXDrwfUBaX8?si=W6H1UvHYXAx2kKsa
Ingredients (4 servings) Babycorn (1 trader joes pack) Cauliflower (half) 1.5 capsicum 1 onion (medium size) 1 tomato 4 green chilly 1 twig curry leaves whole spices (3 cardamom, 0.5 cinamon, 2 cloves, 1 bay leaf) kasuri methi garam masala - 1 or 2 spoons palya powder - 1 spoon coriander - 2 spoons cumin - 1 spoon salt - 2 spoons red chili - 1 spoon Recipe Prep Cut babycorn into slices diagonally Cut cauliflower Cut capsicum vertically Cut onions Cut green chilly Cook Bring oil to hot Add mustard and whole spices Add onion, green chilly and stir Add ginger garlic paste Add tomato Add spices - turmeric, cumin, coriander, kashmiri red chili, red chili, garam masala, salt Add curry leaves let it cook on medium heat for 5mins Turn off flame and let it cool In another pan add the veggies - cauliflower, capsicum, babycorn on stir fry for 5-10mins (use butter also) Grind the onion tomato mixture to fine paste Bring it to heat and let it cook Add the stir fried veggies Let it cook for 5 mins Add the heavy cream and kasuri methi for garnish and taste test.
summary:
Reference:

https://youtube.com/shorts/fzlokaeYOl8?si=yPBfJaqcNrlCywG2

https://youtu.be/SXDrwfUBaX8?si=W6H1UvHYXAx2kKsa

Ingredients (4 servings)

  1. Babycorn (1 trader joes pack)
  2. Cauliflower (half)
  3. 1.5 capsicum
  4. 1 onion (medium size)
  5. 1 tomato
  6. 4 green chilly
  7. 1 twig curry leaves
  8. whole spices (3 cardamom, 0.5 cinamon, 2 cloves, 1 bay leaf)
  9. kasuri methi
  10. garam masala - 1 or 2 spoons
  11. palya powder - 1 spoon
  12. coriander - 2 spoons
  13. cumin - 1 spoon
  14. salt - 2 spoons
  15. red chili - 1 spoon

Recipe

Prep

  1. Cut babycorn into slices diagonally
  2. Cut cauliflower
  3. Cut capsicum vertically
  4. Cut onions
  5. Cut green chilly

Cook

  1. Bring oil to hot
  2. Add mustard and whole spices
  3. Add onion, green chilly and stir
  4. Add ginger garlic paste
  5. Add tomato
  6. Add spices - turmeric, cumin, coriander, kashmiri red chili, red chili, garam masala, salt
  7. Add curry leaves
  8. let it cook on medium heat for 5mins
  9. Turn off flame and let it cool
  10. In another pan add the veggies - cauliflower, capsicum, babycorn on stir fry for 5-10mins (use butter also)
  11. Grind the onion tomato mixture to fine paste
  12. Bring it to heat and let it cook
  13. Add the stir fried veggies
  14. Let it cook for 5 mins
  15. Add the heavy cream and kasuri methi for garnish and taste test.
title: Babycorn Palya

content:
Understanding Rust Data Structures and Ownership Rust is a modern systems programming language that guarantees memory safety and concurrency without a garbage collector. At the heart of Rust’s design are ownership, borrowing, and lifetimes, which play a crucial role in how data structures are implemented and used. This blog explores Rust’s ownership model and common data structures with illustrative code examples.
Common Data Structures Vectors Vectors are dynamic arrays that grow and shrink in size. They’re owned collections, meaning their data is managed by the vector itself.
Example: Using Vectors
fn main() { let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3]; v.push(4); // Add an element println!("{:?}", v); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4] // Iterating over a vector for i in &v { println!("{}", i); } } HashMap Key Value store
Example:
use std::collections::HashMap; fn main() { let mut scores = HashMap::new(); scores.insert("Alice", 50); scores.insert("Bob", 30); // Accessing values if let Some(score) = scores.get("Alice") { println!("Alice's score: {}", score); } // Iterating over the HashMap for (key, value) in &scores { println!("{}: {}", key, value); } } The Ownership Model in Rust Rust’s ownership model has three core rules:
Each value in Rust has a variable called its owner. A value can have only one owner at a time. When the owner goes out of scope, the value is dropped. Example: Ownership and Scope fn main() { let s1 = String::from("hello"); // s1 owns the String let s2 = s1; // Ownership of the String is moved to s2 // println!("{}", s1); // Error: s1 is no longer valid println!("{}", s2); // Output: hello } Borrowing You can have multiple immutable borrows or one mutable borrow, but not both at the same time. A borrow (immutable or mutable) must always be valid for its scope. By enforcing these rules, Rust prevents data races and ensures memory safety at compile time. 1. Mutable Borrow: A mutable borrow gives you the ability to modify the borrowed value, but it enforces exclusivity. Only one mutable borrow is allowed at a time, and no immutable borrows can exist simultaneously.
Example:
fn main() { let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3]; { let v_mut = &mut v; // Mutable borrow v_mut.push(4); // Modifying the vector } // v_mut goes out of scope here println!("{:?}", v); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4] } 2. Reference (Immutable Borrow): An immutable borrow means you can read the value without taking ownership, but you cannot modify it. Multiple immutable borrows are allowed simultaneously because they don’t change the data.
Example:
fn main() { let s = String::from("hello"); let r1 = &s; // Immutable borrow let r2 = &s; // Another immutable borrow println!("{} and {}", r1, r2); // Both r1 and r2 can be used } Borrow conflict example: fn main() { let mut s = String::from("hello"); let r1 = &s; // Immutable borrow // let r2 = &mut s; // Error: Cannot have a mutable borrow while immutable borrows exist println!("{}", r1); }
summary:
Understanding Rust Data Structures and Ownership

Rust is a modern systems programming language that guarantees memory safety and concurrency without a garbage collector. At the heart of Rust’s design are ownership, borrowing, and lifetimes, which play a crucial role in how data structures are implemented and used. This blog explores Rust’s ownership model and common data structures with illustrative code examples.

Common Data Structures

Vectors

Vectors are dynamic arrays that grow and shrink in size. They’re owned collections, meaning their data is managed by the vector itself.
title: Programming in Rust

content:
Reference: Plantain Cake Making
Ingredients For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake
2 ripe plantains 2 cups flour 1 tsp Salt 1 Tsp baking powder 1/4 Tsp baking soda 3/4 cup sugar 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter 1/4 cup Yogurt 2 eggs 3 tbsp milk 1 tsp vanilla extract Recipe Preheat the oven to 350°F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix). Stir in the milk and mix till combined. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional) Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
summary:
Reference:

Plantain Cake Making

Ingredients

For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake

  1. 2 ripe plantains
  2. 2 cups flour
  3. 1 tsp Salt
  4. 1 Tsp baking powder
  5. 1/4 Tsp baking soda
  6. 3/4 cup sugar
  7. 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter
  8. 1/4 cup Yogurt
  9. 2 eggs
  10. 3 tbsp milk
  11. 1 tsp vanilla extract

Recipe

  1. Preheat the oven to 350°F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside.
  2. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda.
  3. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth.
  4. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together.
  5. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix).
  6. Stir in the milk and mix till combined.
  7. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional)
  8. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean.
  9. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
title: Plantaincake

content:
My investment research for USA:
Only invest if: You have no debts You have a 6-month emergency fund You’ve maxed out your 401k You’ve maxed out your IRA Brokerage accounts Fidelity Charles Schwab Vanguard Types of funds: Retirement: Can be taken out past 59.5 years 10% penalty for early withdrawal
401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income) upto $23k per year upto a percentage of the base or a fixed $ amount (whichever comes first) will be contributed by the companies will not be considered as taxable income but will be taxed on capital gains during withdrawal Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal) upto $7k for 2024 can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source) has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth has income limits (MAGI) will not be taxed on any gains during withdrawal Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds Perks of Roth IRA:
You can withdraw your principle contributions anytime Rules Explained Hacks Backdoor Roth Add to traditional IRA first Once you reach 7k, raise a request with your investment app and convert it to Roth IRA If you contributed to roth ira and your income is above the IRS limit, then recharacterize it to traditional IRA (provided it does not have any rollovers) and then do backdoor! (You will be taxed on the gains in between the traditional to backdoor conversion)
Mega Backdoor Roth After taxes contribution can be converted to Roth 401k if the company policy allows. After hitting the Pre-tax and roth contributions (~23.5k USD in 2025) you can contribute to after taxes which won’t be matched This can be converted on every day basis to Roth 401k to avoid taxes on gains and invested. After you seperate from the company, the roth 401k can be converted to an IRA Health Saving Account (HSA) This can be combined with a qualifying High Deductible Plan Limit for 2025 is $4,300 (individual) Some companies contribute some money to this as well Triple tax benefits Excluded from taxable income Gains are not taxed Withdrawals are not taxed if used for health purposes We don’t have to use it right away; keep reciepts and claim it later as well Works for international claims as well Reimburse Invest into a good fund
Investment: Index Funds vs ETF’s:
Index mutual funds can only be bought and sold at the end of the trading day, based on the fund’s net asset value (NAV). ETFs trade throughout the day on a stock exchange, just like stocks, and their price fluctuates based on supply and demand. ETF’s are more tax efficient because they minimize capital gain whereas index funds are more prone to this tax (hasn’t happened in past few years tho) Types of Index funds: Comparison Tool S&P 500: Fidelity SPLG = 0.02% expense ratio VOO = S&P 500 (ETF) VFIAX = S&P 500 (Fund) FXAIX = S&P500 FZROX = (recommended for Roth) zero fees FXNAX = Diversified between US Gov’t and Corporate Bonds Total US Market: VTI = Total US Market Capture (ETF) FSKAX = Total US Market Capture (~3800 companies) VTSAX = Total US Market Capture (Fund) - more for large investment Tech Focused: QQQ and QQQM Mid Cap: VOT Small Cap: AVUV high expense ratio compared to vanguard International: VXUS Overlap between VTI and VXUS = 0 FTIHX = International (outside US) Total Market in World: VT - Vanguard Total World Stock ETF Dividend: Note: Dividends earned are taxed yearly in a taxable brokerage account 1. SCHD 2. VYM = Vanguard High Yield Dividend ETF 3.
Growth: 1. SCHG Detailed Differences Comparison Fidelity Vanguard Charles Schwab Expense Ratio (S&P 500) 0.015% (FXAIX) 0.04% (VFIAX), 0.03% (VOO) 0.02% (SWPPX) Things to Consider before selecting the fund Who runs the fund and how long have they been at the helm. What other funds do they run? What is the fund’s investment strategy? What are the specific risks of this strategy besides the general risks of investing. How has the fund been performing compared to some industry benchmark and other funds with a similar investing strategy. Percentage of diversification (recommended is 70% us market, 20% international, 10% bonds) Expense Ratio How will you be taxed on taxable brokerage withdrawals? On withdrawal of money within 1 year, short term gains tax is applied (which is high) After 1 year, withdrawals are subject to capital gains tax (15% category) Sale of shares is done by default from Fidelity via FIFO i.e earlier shares are sold first to minimize short term gains Terms to Know: Margin Interest Rates:
we can borrow money against the principle being the stock that we own in the brokerage. this is how the brokerages make money. Expense Ratio:
percentage of the investment in the fund that is paid for owning the fund. References: Fidelity vs Vanguard vs Charles Schwab
Index Mutual Funds vs ETFs
Portfolio Management
Average Annual Returns Comparison
Taxation for Gains
HSA limits
Roth IRA Withdrawal rules
Roth Withdrawal With Example boggleheads
summary:
My investment research for USA:

Only invest if:

  • You have no debts
  • You have a 6-month emergency fund
  • You’ve maxed out your 401k
  • You’ve maxed out your IRA

Brokerage accounts

  1. Fidelity
  2. Charles Schwab
  3. Vanguard

Types of funds:

Retirement:

Can be taken out past 59.5 years
10% penalty for early withdrawal

  1. 401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income)
    • upto $23k per year
    • upto a percentage of the base or a fixed $ amount (whichever comes first) will be contributed by the companies
    • will not be considered as taxable income
    • but will be taxed on capital gains during withdrawal
  2. Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal)
    • upto $7k for 2024
    • can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source)
    • has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth
    • has income limits (MAGI)
    • will not be taxed on any gains during withdrawal

Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds
Perks of Roth IRA:
title: IntroToInvesting

Step 1: hugo new –kind page posts/Post_Name.md Step 2: update the content Step 2.5: update base url with hugo -b url Step 3: hugo server Step 4: hugo –minify (prod build)

content:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.
Configuration with Azure Pipelines:
# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration. - task: SonarQubePrepare@3 inputs: SonarQube: # string. scannerMode: 'MSBuild' cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. projectKey: # string. Guidelines:
Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file: <ItemGroup> <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" /> </ItemGroup>
summary:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.

Configuration with Azure Pipelines:

# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration.
- task: SonarQubePrepare@3
  inputs:
    SonarQube: # string. 
    scannerMode: 'MSBuild'
    cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. 
    projectKey: # string.

Guidelines:

  1. Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files.
  2. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file:
<ItemGroup>
    <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" />
</ItemGroup>
title: Sonarcloudlearning
